segments.en: Linked Discourses 11
1. The First Chapter
10. Hermits by the Ocean
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sambahulā isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā samuddatīre paṇṇakuṭīsu sammanti.
segments.en: “Once upon a time, mendicants, several hermits who were ethical, of good character, settled in leaf huts by the ocean.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena devāsurasaṅgāmo samupabyūḷho ahosi.
segments.en: Now at that time a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tesaṃ isīnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ etadahosi:
segments.en: Then the hermits thought,
‘The gods are principled, the demons are unprincipled.
We may be at risk from the demons.

segments.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sambaraṃ asurindaṃ upasaṅkamitvā abhayadakkhiṇaṃ yāceyyāmā’ti.
segments.en: Why don’t we approach Sambara, lord of demons, and beg him for a pledge of safety.’

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—samuddatīre paṇṇakuṭīsu antarahitā sambarassa asurindassa sammukhe pāturahesuṃ.
segments.en: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, those hermits vanished from those leaf huts by the ocean and reappeared in Sambara’s presence.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā sambaraṃ asurindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsiṃsu:
segments.en: Then those hermits addressed Sambara in verse:
‘The hermits have come to Sambara
to beg for a pledge of safety.
For you can give them what you wish,
whether danger or safety.’
‘There is no safety for hermits,
the hated associates of Sakka!
Though you beg me for your safety,
I’ll only give you fear!’
‘Though we beg you for our safety,
you give us only fear.
This is what we get from you:
may endless peril come to you!
Whatever kind of seed you sow,
that is the fruit you reap.
A doer of good gets good,
a doer of bad gets bad.
You have sown your own seed, friend,
now you’ll experience the fruit.’

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā sambaraṃ asurindaṃ abhisapitvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—sambarassa asurindassa sammukhe antarahitā samuddatīre paṇṇakuṭīsu pāturahesuṃ.
segments.en: Then those hermits, having cursed Sambara, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Sambara’s presence and reappeared in those leaf huts by the ocean.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sambaro asurindo tehi isīhi sīlavantehi kalyāṇadhammehi abhisapito rattiyā sudaṃ tikkhattuṃ ubbijjī”ti.
segments.en: But after being cursed by the hermits, Sambara woke in alarm three times that night.”

suttaplex.blurb: In the past, when battle between the gods and demons loomed, some seers sought out the demon lord Sambara to beg for protection. But due to their devotion to Sakka, he rejected them, so they cursed him.
